title: Prompt Engineering & Gemini Nano Banana — Module 2 Quiz

questions.question: In prompt engineering for image generation, which part of a prompt usually comes first?
questions.explanation: The subject is generally described first, followed by style, lighting, camera details.

questions.question: The model -- :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7} (Nano Banana) is especially strong at maintaining object or person consistency across edits.
questions.explanation: Google notes that Gemini 2.5 Flash Image enables character consistency across multiple edits. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

questions.question: Which prompt is most likely to produce a professional product hero shot?

options.text: a red widget, studio lighting, shallow depth of field, white gradient background, 50 mm lens

questions.explanation: Detailed prompts with lighting, lens/focus, background improve quality and control.

questions.question: When editing an uploaded image with Nano Banana, what is a good strategy?

options.text: Upload image → generate from scratch ignoring original
Upload image → use prompt to change only desired part while referencing subject description
Upload image → always use negative prompts to remove unwanted features

questions.explanation: Edit prompts should refer to the subject and specify only the change desired, to maintain consistency. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

questions.question: What does “multi-image fusion” mean in the context of Nano Banana (Gemini 2.5 Flash Image)?

options.text: Generating multiple images and picking one
Merging several input images into a single coherent output using a prompt

questions.explanation: Gemini 2.5 supports merging multiple images into one context via prompts. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

questions.question: In prompt design, adding camera or lens details (e.g., “50 mm lens”, “ultra wide”, “cinematic”) helps give the model stronger style cues.
questions.explanation: Camera/lens terms give style and framing cues which help guide the model’s visualization.
